content:
Suppose we have a commutative quantale Q and a Q-enriched category C, i.e.

  • a set C0 equipped with

  • a function C:C0 x C0 -> Q
    such that

  • for all c in C0, 1 ≤ C(c,c) and

  • for all c1, c2, c3 in C0, C(c2, c3) ⊗ C(c1, c2) ≤ C(c1, c3).
    (The triangle and pentagon equations are trivial.)

We get a poset P(C) of sub-Q-categories of C, which is itself trivially a Q-category because ⊤ and ⊥ are elements of every quantale. However, it seems to me that there should be a construction something like
P(C)(S1,S2)={⊥when S01⊈S02⋀c1,c2∈S1S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2)otherwiseP(C)(S_1, S_2) = \begin{cases} \bot & \text{when } S0_1 \not \subseteq S0_2\\ \bigwedge_{c_1, c_2 \in S_1} S_1(c_1, c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1, c_2) & {\rm otherwise} \end{cases}P(C)(S1​,S2​)={⊥⋀c1​,c2​∈S1​​S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​)​when S01​⊆S02​otherwise​
that can assign values between ⊥ and ⊤ to two sub-Q-categories. When Q is the degenerate quantale of truth values, the construction reduces to the plain poset case, but I'm having trouble proving that it works in the general case.

Has anyone seen this construction before? Does the construction work, or is there a way to show that the plain poset is the best you can do?
What is your definition of "sub-Q-category"?
Isomorphism class of monic Q-functors. As far as I can tell, a Q-functor is monic when the function between the underlying sets is injective.
Okay. I can't parse the relation S01⊈S02S 0_1 \nsubseteq S 0_2S01​⊈S02​ either, but I'm guessing it means that not every object of S1S_1S1​ is also an object of S2S_2S2​.
Yes, it's saying that the underlying set of S1S_1S1​ is not a subset of the underlying set of S2S_2S2​.
How does S01S 0_1S01​ mean "the underlying set of S1S_1S1​"?

Because when I started writing it, I wasn't using latex markup and used C0 to mean the set of elements of C, then was too lazy to fix it when I started using latex. I can go back and edit it if you want.
Ah, I see. No worries.

Anyway it seems easy to me to prove this is a Q-category, but maybe I'm missing something. We have 1≤P(C)(S,S)1 \le P(C)(S,S)1≤P(C)(S,S) since 1≤S(c1,c2)⇒S(c1,c2)1 \le S(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S(c_1,c_2)1≤S(c1​,c2​)⇒S(c1​,c2​) for any c1,c2c_1,c_2c1​,c2​. For transitivity, the only nontrivial case is when ob(S1)⊆ob(S2)⊆ob(S3)\mathrm{ob}(S_1) \subseteq \mathrm{ob}(S_2) \subseteq \mathrm{ob}(S_3)ob(S1​)⊆ob(S2​)⊆ob(S3​), in which case we have to prove P(C)(S2,S3)⊗P(C)(S1,S2)≤S1(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2) P(C)(S_2,S_3) \otimes P(C)(S_1,S_2) \le S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2)P(C)(S2​,S3​)⊗P(C)(S1​,S2​)≤S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​) for any c1,c2c_1,c_2c1​,c2​, and this holds since we have (S2(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2))⊗(S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2))(S_2(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2))\otimes (S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1,c_2))(S2​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​))⊗(S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​)) in the middle.

P(C)(S2,S3)⊗P(C)(S1,S2)≤S1(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2) P(C)(S_2,S_3) \otimes P(C)(S_1,S_2) \le S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2)P(C)(S2​,S3​)⊗P(C)(S1​,S2​)≤S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​)

Why this and not P(C)(S2,S3)⊗P(C)(S1,S2)≤P(C)(S1,S3) P(C)(S_2,S_3) \otimes P(C)(S_1,S_2) \le P(C)(S_1,S_3)P(C)(S2​,S3​)⊗P(C)(S1​,S2​)≤P(C)(S1​,S3​)?

P(C)(S1,S2)P(C)(S_1, S_2)P(C)(S1​,S2​) is the "minimum" (really the meet) over all the implications S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2)S_1(c_1, c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1, c_2)S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​). If the LHS were something as simple as
⋀c1,c2(S2(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2))⊗(S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2))\bigwedge_{c_1, c_2} (S_2(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2))\otimes (S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1,c_2))⋀c1​,c2​​(S2​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​))⊗(S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​))
it would be easy. But it's the product of two meets:
⋀c1,c2(S2(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2))⊗⋀c3,c4(S1(c3,c4)⇒S2(c3,c4))\bigwedge_{c_1, c_2} (S_2(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2))\otimes \bigwedge_{c_3, c_4} (S_1(c_3,c_4) \Rightarrow S_2(c_3,c_4))⋀c1​,c2​​(S2​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​))⊗⋀c3​,c4​​(S1​(c3​,c4​)⇒S2​(c3​,c4​))
where I've changed the second set of variables to emphasize that they're from a different binder.

Mike Stay said:

P(C)(S2,S3)⊗P(C)(S1,S2)≤S1(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2) P(C)(S_2,S_3) \otimes P(C)(S_1,S_2) \le S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2)P(C)(S2​,S3​)⊗P(C)(S1​,S2​)≤S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​)

Why this and not P(C)(S2,S3)⊗P(C)(S1,S2)≤P(C)(S1,S3) P(C)(S_2,S_3) \otimes P(C)(S_1,S_2) \le P(C)(S_1,S_3)P(C)(S2​,S3​)⊗P(C)(S1​,S2​)≤P(C)(S1​,S3​)?

Because P(C)(S1,S3)P(C)(S_1,S_3)P(C)(S1​,S3​) is a meet, so to be less than it, it suffices to be less than all the conjuncts.

Mike Stay said:

P(C)(S1,S2)P(C)(S_1, S_2)P(C)(S1​,S2​) is the "minimum" (really the meet) over all the implications S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2)S_1(c_1, c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1, c_2)S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​). If the LHS were something as simple as
⋀c1,c2(S2(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2))⊗(S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2))\bigwedge_{c_1, c_2} (S_2(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2))\otimes (S_1(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1,c_2))⋀c1​,c2​​(S2​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​))⊗(S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​))
it would be easy. But it's the product of two meets:
⋀c1,c2(S2(c1,c2)⇒S3(c1,c2))⊗⋀c3,c4(S1(c3,c4)⇒S2(c3,c4))\bigwedge_{c_1, c_2} (S_2(c_1,c_2) \Rightarrow S_3(c_1,c_2))\otimes \bigwedge_{c_3, c_4} (S_1(c_3,c_4) \Rightarrow S_2(c_3,c_4))⋀c1​,c2​​(S2​(c1​,c2​)⇒S3​(c1​,c2​))⊗⋀c3​,c4​​(S1​(c3​,c4​)⇒S2​(c3​,c4​))
where I've changed the second set of variables to emphasize that they're from a different binder.

But you still have the relevant projection from each meet. In general, you have ⋀ipi≤pi0\bigwedge_i p_i \le p_{i_0}⋀i​pi​≤pi0​​ and ⋀jqj≤qj0\bigwedge_j q_j \le q_{j_0}⋀j​qj​≤qj0​​, and hence (⋀ipi)⊗(⋀jqj)≤pi0⊗qi0(\bigwedge_i p_i) \otimes (\bigwedge_j q_j) \le p_{i_0} \otimes q_{i_0}(⋀i​pi​)⊗(⋀j​qj​)≤pi0​​⊗qi0​​ by functoriality of ⊗\otimes⊗.
Note that this is really just a sub-Q-category of Qob(C)×ob(C)Q^{\mathrm{ob}(C) \times \mathrm{ob}(C)}Qob(C)×ob(C).
Ah! That was the insight I was missing. Thanks!

Thinking about the metric space case, this feels like an odd definition (or maybe I don't properly understand it). Your definition of a sub-R+\R_+R+​-category of a metric space XXX is a subset equipped with a metric which dominates the original metric. (In other words, a metric space with an injective short map to XXX.) The distance from AAA to BBB is then ∞\infty∞ if AAA is not contained in BBB but is otherwise the maximum of how bigger a distance is in BBB than in AAA. (Is that right?)

The main reason that I say it feels odd is that I've not seen anything like that, I don't think.

What I have seen before for sub-metric spaces of a metric space is the Hausdorff metric. In this case you consider a submetric space to be a subset with the induced metric and the (generalized) distance between two subsets AAA and BBB is sup⁡a∈Ainf⁡b∈Bd(a,b)\sup_{a\in A} \inf_{b\in B} d(a,b)supa∈A​infb∈B​d(a,b), so the furthest you would have to travel to get from somewhere in AAA to BBB. (The traditional Hausdorff distance where is the symmetrized version of this and you need to consider compact subsets in order to get d(A,B)=0d(A,B)=0d(A,B)=0 if and only if A=BA=BA=B, but I'm thinking of R+\R_+R+​-categories so don't need to worry about that.)
If you look at the underlying poset of this then you get something close to the inclusion poset on P(X)P(X)P(X) except, I think A≤BA\le BA≤B if AAA is contained in the closure of BBB.

Anyway, this is generalized to QQQ-categories by Andrei Akhvlediani, Maria Manuel Clementino, Walter Tholen in On the categorical meaning of Hausdorff and Gromov distances, I (see also Andrei's Masters thesis).

For CCC a QQQ-category, they define a QQQ-category structure on the powerset P(CO)P(CO)P(CO) by

P(C0)(S1,S2)=⋀c1∈S1⋁c2∈S2C(c1,c2).P(C0)(S_1,S_2) =\bigwedge_{c_1\in S_1} \bigvee_{c_2\in S_2} C(c_1, c_2).P(C0)(S1​,S2​)=⋀c1​∈S1​​⋁c2​∈S2​​C(c1​,c2​).

I don't know if this is helpful for you!
Hi, Simon!

Mike Stay said:

P(C)(S1,S2)={⊥when S01⊈S02⋀c1,c2∈S1S1(c1,c2)⇒S2(c1,c2)otherwiseP(C)(S_1, S_2) = \begin{cases} \bot & \text{when } S0_1 \not \subseteq S0_2\\ \bigwedge_{c_1, c_2 \in S_1} S_1(c_1, c_2) \Rightarrow S_2(c_1, c_2) & {\rm otherwise} \end{cases}P(C)(S1​,S2​)={⊥⋀c1​,c2​∈S1​​S1​(c1​,c2​)⇒S2​(c1​,c2​)​when S01​⊆S02​otherwise​

Has anyone seen this construction before? Does the construction work, or is there a way to show that the plain poset is the best you can do?

If you interpret this outside of the quantale case, it probably looks like:

P(C)(S1,S2)={⊥when Obj(S1)⊈Obj(S2)Nat(S1(−,=),S2(−,=))otherwiseP(C)(S_1,S_2) = \begin{cases} \bot & \text{when } {\rm Obj}(S_1) \not \subseteq {\rm Obj}(S_2)\\ {\rm Nat}(S_1(-,=),S_2(-,=)) & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}P(C)(S1​,S2​)={⊥Nat(S1​(−,=),S2​(−,=))​when Obj(S1​)⊆Obj(S2​)otherwise​

where in the second case S2S_2S2​ is restricted to the objects of S1S_1S1​. These are also natural transformations of semifunctors on the entirety of Obj(S){\rm Obj}(S)Obj(S) which makes me think it's more natural to define this construction on sub-Q-semicategories where points can have nonzero distance from themselves ...
